de.hshl.obj.data

Class IndexRange

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.hshl.obj.meta.Reflective.DataClass
      • de.hshl.obj.data.IndexRange

  • public final class IndexRange
extends Reflective.DataClass
    Contains a start index and an end index forming an interval. Used to specify a subset of a list.
    Author:
    Johannes Vollmer

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      class  IndexRange.OutOfBoundsException 

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      IndexRange(int exclusiveEnd)
      Create a new IndexRange starting at index 0 inclusively.

      Create a new IndexRange

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      int getExclusiveEnd()
      Where this subset of a list ends, excluding the element at the end index itself.
      int getInclusiveStart()
      Where this subset of a list starts, including the element at the start index itself.
      boolean isValidForLength(int length)
      Is this IndexRange valid for a List of the specified length?
      void throwIfInvalidForLength(int length)
      Throws and IndexRange.OutOfBoundsException if this IndexRange is not valid for a List of the specified length.

    • Method Detail

      • isValidForLength

        public boolean isValidForLength(int length)
        Is this IndexRange valid for a List of the specified length?
        Parameters:
        length - The length of the List which this IndexRange refers to.
        Returns:
        Whether this IndexRange can be used to extract elements off a list with the specified length.

      • throwIfInvalidForLength

        public void throwIfInvalidForLength(int length)
        Throws and IndexRange.OutOfBoundsException if this IndexRange is not valid for a List of the specified length.
        Parameters:
        length - The length of the List which this IndexRange refers to.

      • getInclusiveStart

        public int getInclusiveStart()
        Where this subset of a list starts, including the element at the start index itself.
        Returns:
        The starting index

      • getExclusiveEnd

        public int getExclusiveEnd()
        Where this subset of a list ends, excluding the element at the end index itself.
        Returns:
        One index after the last index
